article.title: Coitus_interruptus

template.arg: Dependent upon self-control. Urinating between acts of sexual intercourse helps clear sperm from urethra.

article.paragraph: Coitus interruptus, also known as therejected sexual intercourse,withdrawalorpull-out method, is a method ofbirth controlin which a man, duringsexual intercourse, withdraws his penis from a woman'svaginaprior to orgasm (andejaculation), and then directs his ejaculate (semen) away from the vagina in an effort to avoidinsemination.

This method ofcontraception, widely used for at least two millennia, is still in use today. This method was used by an estimated 38 million couples worldwide in 1991.cite journalRogow D, Horowitz SWithdrawal: a review of the literature and an agenda for researchStudies in family planning263140–531995757076410.2307/21378332137833, which cites:
Population Action International(1991). "A Guide to Methods of Birth Control." Briefing Paper No. 25, Washington, D. C.Coitus interruptus does not protect againstSexually transmitted diseasesexually transmitted infections(STIs/STDs).cite journalCreatsas GSexuality: sexual activity and contraception during adolescenceCurr Opin Obstet Gynecol56774–831993828668910.1097/00001703-199312000-00011
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: Perhaps the oldest documentation of the use of the withdrawal method to avoid pregnancy is the story ofOnanin theTorah. This text is believed to have been written down over 2,500 years ago.cite webAdamsCecilCecil AdamsWho wrote the Bible? (Part 1)The Straight DopeCreative Loafing Media, Inc.2002-01-07http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/1985/who-wrote-the-bible-part-12009-07-24Societies in the ancient civilizations ofAncient GreeceGreeceandRoman EmpireRomepreferred small families and are known to have practiced a variety of birth control methods.rp12,16–17There are references that have led historians to believe withdrawal was sometimes used as birth control.cite bookBullough, Vern L.Encyclopedia of birth controlABC-CLIOSanta Barbara, Calif200174–751-57607-181-2http://books.google.com/?id2009-07-24However, these societies viewed birth control as a woman's responsibility, and the only well-documented contraception methods were female-controlled devices (both possibly effective, such aspessarypessaries, and ineffective, such asamulets).cite bookAineCollier2007The Humble Little Condom: A HistoryPrometheus BooksAmherst, NY978-1-59102-556-6rp17,23

After thedecline of the Roman Empirein the 5th century AD, contraceptive practices fell out of use in Europe; the use of contraceptive pessaries, for example, is not documented again until the 15th century. If withdrawal was used during the Roman Empire, knowledge of the practice may have been lost during its decline.rp33,42
From the 18th century until the development of modern methods, withdrawal was one of the most popular methods of birth-control in Europe, North America, and elsewhere.
article.heading: Effects
article.paragraph:
Like many methods of birth control, reliable effect is achieved only by correct and consistent use. Observed failure rates of withdrawal vary depending on the population being studied: studies have found actual failure rates of 1528% per year.cite bookJohnKippleySheila Kippley1996The Art of Natural Family Planning4th additionThe Couple to Couple LeagueCincinnati, OH0-926412-13-2146, which cites:
cite journalGuttmacher InstituteChoice of ContraceptivesThe Medical Letter on Drugs and Therapeutics34111–11419921448019885
cite bookRAHatcherTrussel JStewart F1994Contraceptive TechnologySixteenth RevisedIrvington PublishersNew York0-8290-3171-5etalIn comparison,combined oral contraceptive pillthe pillhas an actual use failure rate of 28%,cite journalAudet MC, Moreau M, Koltun WD, Waldbaum AS, Shangold G, Fisher AC, Creasy GWEvaluation of contraceptive efficacy and cycle control of a transdermal contraceptive patch vs an oral contraceptive: a randomized controlled trialJAMA20012347–542851811343482http://www.contraceptiononline.org/slides/slide01.cfm?qSlides of comparative efficacy]10.1001/jama.285.18.2347
cite webGuttmacher InstituteGuttmacher Institutehttp://www.agi-usa.org/pubs/fb_contr_use.htmlContraceptive UseFacts in BriefGuttmacher Institute2005-05-10- see tableFirst-Year Contraceptive Failure Rateswhile theintrauterine device(IUD) has an actual use failure rate of 0.8%.Thecondomhas an actual use failure rate of 1018%.However, some authors suggest that actual effectiveness of withdrawal could be similar to effectiveness of condoms, and this area needs further research.cite journalJones RK, Fennell J, Higgins JA, Blanchard KBetter than nothing or savvy risk-reduction practice? The importance of withdrawalContraception796407–10June 20091944277310.1016/j.contraception.2008.12.008http://www.guttmacher.org/pubs/journals/reprints/Contraception79-407-410.pdf2009-07-23PDF(seeComparison of birth control methods)

For couples that use coitus interruptus correctly at every act of intercourse, the failure rate is 4% per year. In comparison, the pill has a perfect-use failure rate of 0.3%, and the I.U.D. has a perfect-use failure rate of 0.6%. The condom has a perfect-use failure rate of 2%.cite bookRAHatcherTrussel JStewart F2000Contraceptive Technology18thArdent MediaNew York0-9664902-6-6http://www.contraceptivetechnology.com/table.htmletal

It has been suggested that thepre-ejaculate("Cowper's fluid") emitted by the penis prior to ejaculation normally containsSpermatozoonspermatozoa(sperm cells), which would compromise the effectiveness of the method.cite webRoger W.HarmsCan pre-ejaculation fluid cause pregnancy?Women's health: Expert answersMayoClinic.comhttp://www.mayoclinic.com/health/birth-control/an001972007-09-202009-07-15cite webTraceeCornforthHow effective is withdrawal as a birth control method?About.com: Women's Healthhttp://womenshealth.about.com/cs/birthcontro1/a/withdrawalbircn.htm2003-12-022009-07-15However, several small studiescite journalZukermanZ.Short Communication: Does Preejaculatory Penile Secretion Originating from Cowper's Gland Contain Sperm?Journal of Assisted Reproduction and Genetics204157–159April 20031276241510.1023/A:1022933320700WeissDBOrvietoR3455634cite journalFree M, Alexander NMale contraception without prescription. A reevaluation of the condom and coitus interruptusPublic Health Rep915437–4519768246681440560cite journalResearchers find no sperm in pre-ejaculate fluidContraceptive Technology Update1410154–156October 199312286905cite webClark, S.Sep 1981An examination of the sperm content of human pre-ejaculatory fluid[Unpublished]http://www.popline.org/node/425048have failed to find any viable sperm in the fluid. While no large conclusive studies have been done, it is believed by some that the cause of method (correct-use) failure is the pre-ejaculate fluid picking up sperm from a previous ejaculation.cite webWithdrawal Method[[Planned Parenthood]]March 2004http://www.plannedparenthood.com/health-topics/birth-control/withdrawal-pull-out-method-4218.htm2008-03-28cite webDelvinDavidCoitus interruptus (Withdrawal method)NetDoctor.co.uk2005-01-17http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/sex_relationships/facts/coitusinterruptus.htm2006-07-13For this reason, it is recommended that the male partner urinate between ejaculations, to clear the urethra of sperm, and wash any ejaculate from objects that might come near the woman's vulva (e.g. hands and penis).

However, recent research suggests that this might not be accurate. A contrary, yet non-generalizable study that found mixed evidence, including individual cases of a high sperm concentration, was published in March 2011.Cite journalKillick SR, Leary C, Trussell J, Guthrie KA.10.3109/14647273.2010.5207982011Sperm content of pre-ejaculatory fluidHuman Fertility14148–52http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.3109/14647273.2010.520798211556893564677A noted limitation to these previous studies' findings is that pre-ejaculate samples were analyzed after the critical two-minute point. That is, looking for motile sperm in small amounts of pre-ejaculate via microscope after two minutes when the sample has most likely dried makes examination and evaluation "extremely difficult."Thus, in March 2011 a team of researchers assembled 27 male volunteers and analyzed their pre-ejaculate samples within two minutes after producing them. The researchers found that 11 of the 27 men (41%) produced pre-ejaculatory samples that contained sperm, and 10 of these samples (37%) contained a "fair amount" of motile sperm (i.e. as few as 1 million to as many as 35 million).This study therefore recommends, in order to minimise unintended pregnancy and disease transmission, the use of condom from the first moment of genital contact.As a point of reference, a study showed that, of couples who conceived within a year of trying, only 2.5% included a male partner with a total sperm count (per ejaculate) of 23 million sperm or less.cite journalCooperT.G.Noonan, E.von Eckaedstein, S.Auger, J.Baker, H.W.G.Behre, H.M.World Health Organisation reference values for human semen characteristicsHuman Reproduction Update201016231–24510.1093/humupd/dmp048199342133etalHowever, across a wide range of observed values, total sperm count (as with other identified semen and sperm characteristics) has weak power to predict which couples are at risk of pregnancy.cite journalSlamaR.Eustache, F.Time to pregnancy and semen parameters: a cross-sectional study among fertile couples from four European citiesHuman Reproduction200217513210.1093/humrep/17.2.503etal

It is widely believed that urinating after an ejaculation will flush the urethra of remaining sperm.Cite webWithdrawal MethodPlanned ParenthoodMarch 2004http://www.plannedparenthood.com/health-topics/birth-control/withdrawal-pull-out-method-4218.htm2006-09-01Therefore, some of the subjects in the March 2011 study who produced sperm in their pre-ejaculate did urinate (sometimes more than once) before producing their sample.
article.heading: Advantages
article.paragraph: The advantage of coitus interruptus is that it can be used by people who have objections to or do not have access to other forms of contraception. Some men prefer it so they can avoid possible adverse effects ofhormonal contraceptiveson their partners or so that they can have a full experience and really be able to "feel" their partner.cite journalOrtayli, NWhy Withdrawal? Why not withdrawal? Men's perspectivesReproductive Health Matters20051325164–731603561010.1016/S0968-8080(05)25175-3BulutAOzugurluMCokarMSome women also prefer this method over hormonal contraception to avoid adverse effects such as depression, mood swings, vaginal dryness, decreased libido, weight gain, nausea, and headaches, among others. It has no direct monetary cost, requires no artificial devices, has no physical side effects, can be practiced without a prescription or medical consultation, and provides no barriers to stimulation.
article.heading: Disadvantages
article.paragraph: Compared to the other common reversible methods of contraception such asIUDs, hormonal contraceptives and male condoms, coitus interruptus is less effective at preventing pregnancy.As a result, it is also less cost-effective than many more effective methods: although the method itself has no direct cost, users have a greater chance of incurring the risks and expenses of either child-birth or abortion. Only models that assume all couples practice perfect use of the method find cost savings associated with the choice of withdrawal as a birth control method.cite journalAmerican Journal of Public HealthThe economic value of contraception: a comparison of 15 methodsJames TrusellApril 1995854494–503http://www.ajph.org/cgi/reprint/85/4/494.pdf10.2105/AJPH.85.4.4947702112LevequeJAKoenigJDLondonRBordenSHenneberryJLaguardiaKDStewartFWilsonTG81615115

The method is largely ineffective in the prevention ofSexually transmitted diseasesexually transmitted infections(STIs/STDs), likeHIV, sincepre-ejaculatemay carry viral particles or bacteria which may infect the partner if this fluid comes in contact with mucous membranes. However, a reduction in the volume of bodily fluids exchanged during intercourse may reduce the likelihood of disease transmission compared to using no method due to the smaller number of pathogens present.

The method may be difficult for some couples to use. The interruption of intercourse may leave some couples sexually frustrated or dissatisfied.cite webCoitus Interruptus (Withdrawal)Abstinence & Natural Birth Control MethodsSexually Transmitted Disease Resource2006http://www.sexual-health-resource.org/natural_birth_control.htm#withdrawal2006-09-05

Masters and Johnsonconsidered withdrawal as a means to developingsexual dysfunctionsexual problems, e.g.premature ejaculationanderectile dysfunction,cite bookMasters, W.H., & Johnson, V.E.1970Human sexual inadequacyBostonLittle, Brown and Companybut there is no known evidence to support this.
article.heading: Prevalence
article.paragraph: Worldwide, 3% of women of childbearing age rely on withdrawal as their primary method of contraception. Regional popularity of the method varies widely, from a low of 1% on the African continent to 16% in Western Asia. (Data from surveys during the late 1990s).cite journalFamily Planning Worldwide: 2002 Data SheetPopulation Reference Bureau2002http://www.prb.org/pdf/FamPlanWorldwide_Eng.pdfPDF2006-09-14

In the United States, studies have indicated 56% of women of reproductive age have had a partner use withdrawal. By 2002, only 2.5% were using withdrawal as their primary method of contraception.cite journalChandraAMartinezGMMosherWDAbmaJCJonesJFertility, Family Planning, and Reproductive Health of U.S. Women: Data From the 2002 National Survey of Family GrowthNational Center for Health StatisticsVital and Health Statistics23252005http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/series/sr_23/sr23_025.pdfPDF2007-05-20See Tables 53 and 56.

A leading exponent of withdrawal in the mid-19th century was a religious based "utopian commune" called theOneida communityin New York. To minimize the incidence of pregnancy, teenage males were not permitted to engage in sexual intercourse except withpostmenopausalwomen until such time as they mastered the withdrawal technique.citation neededMarch 2011
